awd_titl_txt: Moduli Space of Canonical Metrics on Four-Manifolds
awd_abstract_narration:
For more than a century, mathematicians specializing in the subject of differential geometry have worked on the question of what is the best geometry (i.e., shape) that a given space can have: Just as a beachball can be shaped into a perfect sphere, with the same amount of curvature at all points and in all directions, all 2-dimensional spaces can be shaped into highly symmetric and uniform geometries, and similarly all 3-dimensional spaces can be cut into pieces that carry such geometries. But the corresponding question is completely open for 4-dimensional spaces.  Moreover, this dimension stands out among others, since certain 4-dimensional spaces can support infinitely many different smooth structures, which may admit geometries with radically different properties. These facts make 4-dimensional geometry in many ways unpredictable, and a fertile field for interdisciplinary research, as the subject has grown in many directions and branched into other areas of mathematics and physics.  This research project is based on interactions between fields including geometry, topology, and analysis.  The investigator will undertake an in-depth analysis of a class of unbounded 4-dimensional spaces that are important from the perspective of general relativity, that carry a geometry modeled on the complex numbers, and whose geometry is mildly uniform. In another direction, the investigator will examine closed 4-dimensional spaces whose curvature is similarly uniform. 
 
In more detail, the investigator will undertake a comprehensive analysis of the asymptotically locally Euclidean Kähler manifolds. This is a special class of non-compact 4-dimensional manifolds that generalizes the gravitational instantons from theoretical physics. The project has far-reaching applications in understanding the global structure of closed constant scalar curvature Kähler or almost-Kähler manifolds. A second group of projects focuses on the study of the Riemannian properties of 4-manifolds in conjunction with techniques coming from Seiberg-Witten theory. In particular, the investigator will analyze the moduli space of Einstein metrics or constant scalar curvature metrics and their compactifications in Gromov-Hausdorff topology. The techniques employed come from gauge theory, global analysis, algebraic geometry, and differential topology.

por.por_cntn:
The main research conducted during the period of the award was on the study of complete scalar flat Kahler manifolds. These spaces are natural generalizations of space-time models, described as gravitational instantons in mathematical physics. They are of interest to both physicists and mathematicians, and the area received an infusion of ideas and rapid development in the last decade. In particular, the methods employed are from several disciplines: complex differential geometry, complex analysis, and algebraic geometry. All these areas become interconnected and shed light on each other. Significant results achieved by the PI are the classification of the underlying complex structures of ALE Kahler manifolds and a characterization of Moishezon uniruled manifolds in terms of the positivity of the total Chern scalar curvature of a balanced metric. These set the background to the study of ALE Kahler manifolds and answered several open questions for Hermitian manifolds, respectively.

During the period of the award, the PI supervised one graduate student, Sam Rizzo (PhD 2023) and a postdoctoral researcher, Mitchell Faulk (2019-2022). She was also the undergraduate advisor of many undergraduate students, many of whom were women. As the Associate Director for Graduate Studies (2020-2023), she has overseen the general mentoring of graduate students in the department. In particular, she organized a panel on graduate student professional development and taught a weekly Teaching Seminar. 

The PI taught a variety of graduate and undergraduate courses covering both a general background in mathematics and advanced courses in geometry and topology. In additional to the department's teaching assignments the PI offered several independent study courses and supervised two honor theses in mathematics (both students are now enrolled in graduate programs). 

The PI is co-organizing the Geometry Seminar and organized three two days workshops in Spring 2018, 2020 and Fall 2021, as well as an AMS Special Session in Spring 2018. The main goal was multifaceted: to stimulate propagation of new results, establish new collaborations and disseminate research in the general area of differential geometry. The PI paid close attention to the participation of under-represented minorities in these activities. At least 25% of the speakers were women mathematicians. She also supported the junior mathematicians, by having at least 40% of the speakers recent PhDs and covered the participation cost in the workshops for all graduate students and postdocs.
